billEvents.eventText: REFERRED TO COMMERCE, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND SMALL BUSINESS

title: Creates a sustainable development task force to study the feasibility of adopting a regulatory system to achieve goal of sustainable development
summary: Creates a fifteen member sustainable development task force to study the feasibility of adopting a goal oriented and performance based regulatory system to achieve the goal of sustainable development in the state; sets forth certain goals and makes provision for organization of the task force.
currentCommittee: COMMERCE, ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT AND SMALL BUSINESS

       Introduced  by  Sens.  PARKER, ADAMS, PERKINS, SAMPSON -- read twice and
         ordered printed, and when printed to be committed to the Committee  on
         Commerce, Economic Development and Small Business

       AN ACT creating a sustainable development task force to study the feasi-
         bility  of  adopting  goal  oriented  and performance based regulatory
         systems to achieve a goal of sustainable development for the state  of
         New York

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. As used in this act, the term:
    2    (1) "Benchmarks" means interim indicators that measure the progress in
    3  achieving measurable objectives and long term measurable goals.
    4    (2) "Long term measurable goals" means the attainment of the condition
    5  for a parameter that is necessary  to  achieve  sustainable  development
    6  within 25 years.
    7    (3)  "Measurable objectives" means measurable achievements at specific
    8  points in time, typically in two- to five-year segments  that  over  the
    9  duration achieve long term measurable goals.
   10    (4)  "Sustainable development" means managing the use, development and
   11  protection of natural and physical resources in a way,  or  at  a  rate,
   12  that enables people to meet their current needs without compromising the
   13  ability of future generations to meet their own needs.
   14    S 2. The legislature finds and declares that:
   15    (1)  In  order to establish a policy of sustainable development neces-
   16  sary for economic competitiveness in the twenty-first century, the state
   17  must achieve the following intermediate value goals:
   18    (a) A competitive and balanced economy;
   19    (b) A healthy environment;
   20    (c) A continuing resource base; and
   21    (d) Communities that provide a good quality of life, for both  current
   22  and future generations of New Yorkers.

        EXPLANATION--Matter in ITALICS (underscored) is new; matter in brackets
                             [ ] is old law to be omitted.

       S. 1100                             2

    1    (2)  Although  New  York state has made progress towards the goals set
    2  forth in subdivision one of this section, it lacks an integrated strate-
    3  gy for achieving these goals concurrently.  It  also  lacks  established
    4  mechanisms  for  measuring  the  success  of  activities  implemented to
    5  achieve these goals.
    6    (3) To develop an integrated strategy for achieving the four goals set
    7  forth  in  subdivision  one  of  this  section,  and thus establishing a
    8  sustainable development policy, the state must:
    9    (a) Examine the feasibility of establishing clear, long  term  measur-
   10  able goals for environmental and natural resource stewardship along with
   11  measurable objectives and interim benchmarks to monitor progress towards
   12  the goals;
   13    (b)  Examine  a performance based system in which long term measurable
   14  goals can be attained by carefully monitored and self-generated,  incen-
   15  tive  based  strategies that improve the efficiency and effectiveness of
   16  environmental management and regulation for businesses, communities  and
   17  government; and
   18    (c)  Integrate  environmental and natural resource goals with economic
   19  and societal goals.
   20    S 3. In order to achieve the goals set forth  in  subdivision  one  of
   21  section  two  of  this act, the state shall examine an environmental and
   22  natural resource management system that is based on a policy of sustain-
   23  able development and that:
   24    (1) Establishes clear long term measurable goals and measurable objec-
   25  tives;
   26    (2) Is incentive based and performance oriented;
   27    (3) Allows attainment of superior environmental and  natural  resource
   28  management performance by adoption of a performance track in which enti-
   29  ties  would be held accountable for achieving long term measurable goals
   30  but have freedom to choose how to accomplish them;
   31    (4) Assures predictability for participants;
   32    (5) Is integrated, cross media, cross agency and flexible;
   33    (6) Focuses on managing the causes of environmental degradation rather
   34  than simply impacts;
   35    (7) Concentrates on issues of long term ecological significance; and
   36    (8) Achieves the objectives of subdivisions  one,  two,  three,  four,
   37  five,  six and seven of this section in the most cost-effective, econom-
   38  ically accommodating and community oriented manner.
   39    S 4. (1) A sustainable development task force  is  hereby  created  to
   40  conduct  the  examination  described  in  section  three of this act and
   41  determine the viability of adopting  a  goal  oriented  and  performance
   42  based  regulatory system with sustainable development as the overarching
   43  environmental policy for the state.
   44    (2) The task force shall consist of fifteen members, each to serve for
   45  a term of two years, to be appointed as follows: two shall be  appointed
   46  by  the temporary president of the senate and one by the minority leader
   47  of the senate; two shall be appointed by the speaker of the assembly and
   48  one by the minority leader of the assembly; seven shall be appointed  by
   49  the  governor.    The  appointees shall be broadly representative of the
   50  geographic areas of the state and include representatives  of  industry,
   51  public  interest groups and local government and the public at large. No
   52  more than four appointees shall be  legislators.  Commissioners  of  the
   53  department  of environmental conservation and the department of economic
   54  development shall be ex-officio members. The  governor  shall  designate
   55  the  chairman  and vice chairman from among his appointees. Vacancies in

       S. 1100                             3

    1  the membership of the commission and among its officers shall be  filled
    2  in the manner provided for original appointments.
    3    (3) The task force may employ and at pleasure remove such personnel as
    4  it may deem necessary for the performance of its functions and fix their
    5  compensation within the amounts made available therefor.
    6    (4)  The  task force may meet within and without the state, shall hold
    7  public hearings, and shall have all the powers of a legislative  commit-
    8  tee pursuant to the legislative law.
    9    (5)  The  members  of the task force shall receive no compensation for
   10  their services, but shall be allowed their actual and necessary expenses
   11  incurred in the performance of their duties hereunder.
   12    (6) To the maximum extent feasible, the task force shall  be  entitled
   13  to  request  and  receive  and  shall  utilize and be provided with such
   14  facilities, resources, and data  of  any  court,  department,  division,
   15  board,  bureau,  commission,  or  agency  of  the state or any political
   16  subdivision thereof as it may reasonably request to carry  out  properly
   17  its powers and duties hereunder.
   18    S  5. In accordance with the requirements established by the sustaina-
   19  ble development task force, the departments of  environmental  conserva-
   20  tion,  economic  development, agriculture and markets, and parks, recre-
   21  ation and historic preservation and any other agency or  public  benefit
   22  corporation  deemed  appropriate  by  the task force shall determine the
   23  following and report to the task force:
   24    (1) The degree to which a state policy of sustainable development will
   25  assist the agency in carrying out its mission.
   26    (2) Methods for establishing long term  measurable  goals  to  achieve
   27  sustainable  development, including interim benchmarks from the agency's
   28  perspective.
   29    (3) How collaboration would occur with other governmental entities and
   30  state agencies under a policy of sustainable development.
   31    (4) Changes to statutes,  rules,  policies,  intergovernmental  agree-
   32  ments, strategic plans, relationships with private and nonprofit sectors
   33  and  the  agency's organization and processes that would be necessary to
   34  implement a policy of sustainable development.
   35    (5) Whether resources are being allocated in reasonable proportion  to
   36  the  ecological significance of sustainable development and the resource
   37  allocation changes necessary to bring the allocation into proper propor-
   38  tion.
   39    (6) The extent to which new systems  can  be  developed,  particularly
   40  incentive  based  programs, to achieve measurable superior environmental
   41  protection and natural resource management.
   42    S 6. The appointing authorities  shall  appoint  the  members  of  the
   43  sustainable  development  task force on or before 90 days after this act
   44  shall have become a law and the task force shall convene its first meet-
   45  ing on or before 60 days thereafter.
   46    S 7. The task force shall make a preliminary report  to  the  governor
   47  and the legislature of its findings, conclusions, and recommendations by
   48  the one hundred twentieth day after the effective date of this act and a
   49  final report of its findings, conclusions, and recommendations not later
   50  than  one  year  after  the effective date of this act, and shall submit
   51  with its reports such legislative proposals as  it  deems  necessary  to
   52  implement its recommendations.
   53    S  8.  This  act shall take effect on the ninetieth day after it shall
   54  have become a law.
